facts.text: Appeals are Civil Appeals Nos. 55-157 of 1964 by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 8, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 25 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos./55--157 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 8, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 25 of 1957.

facts.text: Cocanada Bank Ltd., Kakinada is a private limited company carrying on banking business with head office at Kakinada and a branch at Dayal Bagh.

anchor.surface_text: The, Cocanada Bank Ltd., Kakinada, hereinafter called the assessee, is a private limited companypany carrying on banking business with its head office at Kakinada and a branch at Dayal Bagh.

facts.text: Assessee's sources of income are banking business and interest from government securities.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees sources of income are banking business and interest from government securities.

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, assessee's income assessed as interest on securities Rs. 84,880, other banking activities loss Rs. 64,400, net loss Rs. 55,912.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 194950 its income was assessed as follows Interest on securities Rs. 84,880 Other banking activities Rs. 64,400  loss  ------------------ --- Net loss Rs. 55,912 --------------------

facts.text: For assessment year 1950-51, interest on securities Rs. 5,191, business income or loss Rs. 886, total Rs. 6,077 as decided by A.A.C.

anchor.surface_text: The following tabular form shows at a glance the factual position in regard to the income of the assessee under different heads during the said three years Business Year of assessment Interest on income or securities loss as finally Total decided by the A.A.C. 1 2 3 4 Rs. Rs. Rs. 1. 1950-51 5,191 886 6077

facts.text: For assessment year 1951-52, interest on securities Rs. 2,174, business income Rs. 1,177, total Rs. 3,351 as decided by A.A.C.
For assessment year 1952-53, interest on securities Rs. 1,885, business income Rs. 9,121, total Rs. 11,006 as decided by A.A.C.
Department allowed the loss to be set off against business income but disallowed against interest on securities for three succeeding years.

anchor.surface_text: For the three succeeding years the department showed the income under the said two separate heads but allowed the said loss to be set off against the income under the head business and disallowed it against the income under the head interest on securties.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer's view was confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed, on appeal, by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

facts.text: Income-tax Officer's view confirmed by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on further appeal.

anchor.surface_text: and, on further appeal, by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: whether assessee entitled to set off business loss of Rs. 55,912 against entire income including interest on securities.

anchor.surface_text: The following question was referred by the Tribunal to the High Court for its opinion Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee was entitled to set off the business loss of Rs. 55,912 brought forward from the preceding year against the entire income including interest on securities held by the assessee.

facts.text: High Court remitted case to Income-tax Tribunal citing United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. CIT for fuller statement on whether securities formed part of trading assets.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, having regard to the decision of this Court in United Commercial Bank Ltd., Calcutta v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bangal 1  remitted the case to the Income- tax Tribunal, Hyderabad Bench, for making a fuller statement of case on the question whether these securities in question formed part of the trading assets held by the assessee in the companyrse of its business as a banker

facts.text: Income-tax Tribunal held that receipt of interest from securities was part of assessee's business as other banking activities.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Tribunal, on a further hearing, held that the receipt of interest from securities was as much the assessees business as its other banking activities like receiving deposits from the clients and withdrawals by them.

facts.text: High Court answered the reference in favour of the assessee on receipt of supplementary statement from Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the supplementary statement of case from the Tribunal the High Court answered the reference in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Revenue filed present appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the present appeals.

facts.text: Tribunal and High Court found that securities were assessee's trading assets and income therefrom was income of the business.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court found that they were the assessees trading assets and the income therefrom was, therefore, the income of the business.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that income from securities was income from business if securities part of trading assets.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided number on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on companymercial principles. To put it in other words, did the securities in the present case which yielded the income form part of the trading assets of the assessee?

facts.text: Assessee invested amounts in easily realisable securities which were part of trading assets of banking business.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Tribunal held, on the evidence, and that was accepted by the High Court, that the assessee was investing its amounts in easily realisable securities and, therefore, the said securities were part of the trading assets of the assessees banking business.

facts.text: Counsel for Revenue argued that income from business and securities under different heads s.10 and s.8, mutually exclusive, losses not set off under s.24(2).

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the Revenue argued that the income from business and securities fell under different heads, namely, s. 10 and s. 8 of the Act respectively, that they were mutually exclusive and, therefore, the losses under the head business companyld number be carried forward from the preceding year to the succeeding year and set off under s. 22 4  of the Act against the income from securities held by the assessee.

facts.text: Counsel for assessee contended that securities part of trading assets, income therefrom part of business income, losses set off against total business income.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the assessee, on the other hand, companytended that though for the purpose of companyputation of income, the income from securities and the income from business were calculated separately, in a case where the securities were part of the trading assets of the business, the income therefrom was part of the income of the business

issues.text: the question of construction of s. 24(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: construction of s. 24 2  of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee was entitled to set off the business loss of Rs. 55,912 brought forward from the preceding year against the entire income including interest on securities held by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The following question was referred by the Tribunal to the High Court for its opinion Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee was entitled to set off the business loss of Rs. 55,912 brought forward from the preceding year against the entire income including interest on securities held by the assessee.

issues.text: whether these securities in question formed part of the trading assets held by the assessee in the course of its business as a banker and whether its dealing with the securities from which it received interest was as much the assessees business as receiving deposits from clients and withdrawals by them.

anchor.surface_text: the question whether these securities in question formed part of the trading assets held by the assessee in the course of its business as a banker and whether its dealing with the securities from which it received interest was as much the assessees business as receiving deposits from clients and withdrawals by them.

issues.text: The question, therefore, is whether the securities formed part of the trading assets of the business and the income therefrom was income from the business.

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, is whether the securities formed part of the trading assets of the business and the income therefrom was income from the business.

issues.text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles.

issues.text: whether the income from securities is part of the income from business if the securities are part of the trading assets

anchor.surface_text: Though for the purpose of computation of the income, interest on securities is separately classified, income by way of interest from securities does not cease to be part of the income from business if the securities are part of the trading assets.

anchor.surface_text: The following question was referred by the Tribunal to the High Court for its opinion Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee was entitled to set off the business loss of Rs. 55,912 brought forward from the preceding year against the entire income including interest on securities held by the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Securities formed part of trading assets on evidence accepted from Tribunal and High Court; income therefrom is business income determined by commercial principles overriding s.6 classification; s.24(2) permits set off against profits from same business without reference to heads.

holdings.text: Income by way of interest from securities does not cease to be part of the income from business if the securities are part of the trading assets.

anchor.surface_text: Though for the purpose of computation of the income, interest on securities is separately classified, income by way of interest from securities does not cease to be part of the income from business if the securities are part of the trading assets.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 classifies for computation of net income only; true character of income as business income determined by whether assets are trading assets on commercial principles.

holdings.text: Whether a particular income is part of the income from a business falls to be decided not on the basis of the provisions of s. 6 but on commercial principles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act levies one tax; s.6 heads only for computation; business connection tested commercially by trading assets.

holdings.text: The securities in question formed part of the trading assets held by the assessee in the course of its business as a banker.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Tribunal held, on the evidence, and that was accepted by the High Court, that the assessee was investing its amounts in easily realisable securities and, therefore, the said securities were part of the trading assets of the assessees banking business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal finding on evidence that investments in easily realisable securities for banking demands accepted by High Court and this Court; aligns with Punjab Cooperative Bank on banking business nature.

holdings.text: Section 24(2) permits carrying forward of business loss to be set off against profits and gains from the same business without reference to heads under s.6.
